awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small : Collaborative Research: Harnessing Network Coding Gains in Multi-Rate Wireless Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Network coding brings the promise of increased wireless network capacity by decreasing the overall number of
transmissions. In practice however, many challenges remain in realizing the gains from network coding. In particular
the interactions between network coding and transmission rate control have not been carefully studied to date.
While transmission at higher rates favor a capacity increase, they can diminish overhearing possibilities, a key requirement
of network coding.
This proposal considers the problem of transmission rate control and network coding in a holistic
way. A framework that examines the interdependencies between the use of network coding and multiple transmission
rates with respect to various functions  spanning the link and routing layers, is developed.


The following tasks are being undertaken: (i) Design a network-coding aware transmission rate control module
that allows nodes to transmit at the high bit rates while at the same time facilitating network coding.
(ii) Design a set of functions at the link and routing layers that provide the best trade-offs between applying
network coding and controlling interference and network congestion
(iii) Implement and extensively evaluate a unified framework combining all of our functional modules on wireless testbeds.

The proposed research is tightly knit with  new education programs by establishing wireless teaching
laboratories and introduce cross-disciplinary courses that bridge the physical and higher layers.

por.por_cntn:
The project investigates the use of network coding in multi-rate settings. Unlike in single rate settings, we show that applying network coding blindly in multi-rate settings could in fact hurt the achieved wireless throughput capacity.  We undertake a comprehensive study to determine when and how to apply network coding.

Intellectual Merits: We make the following contributions in this project.

A. We show that blindly applying network coding in multi-rate settings could hurt the network capacity. We determine the conditions conducive to network coding, and design a framework PACE, that adaptively switches between using network coding and store-and-forward policies to derive the highest throughput.

B. We develop novel approaches for joint adminstration of network coding and transmission rate control. Specifically, our approaches recognize that overhearing is a fundamental requirement for effectively encoding packets. Thus, in one approach the rate is maximized while imposing some requirements on the overhearing probabilities. In a second approach, we design a stochastic rate selection algorithm that chooses the transmission rates with the knowledge that network coding is to be applied. Both approaches result in significant capacity gains.

C. We recognize that a relay that performs network coding needs to have packets from distinct flows for it to effectively encode packets.If the relay does not have packets destined for distinct destinations, the network coding gains could be marginal. We design a novel queue management scheme whcih arbitrates the rates at which different transmitters send packets to a common relay that applies network coding.

D. We have undertaken a fundamental study to determine the network coding efficiency in case, the backhaul connectivity is intermittent.

 

Broader Impacts:
The understanding developed in this project could significantly influence the use of network coding in future wireless networks and enhancing network capacity.  A new undergraduate course on wireless networking was created and offered multiple times. The project resulted in supporting multiple Ph.D students at UCR, of which one was a female student. Two of these students have found jobs in industry.
